issue.title: thread::join() effects?

discussion.p: While looking at thread::join() I think I spotted a couple of possible defects in the specifications. I could not find a previous issue or NB comment about that, but I might have missed it.
The postconditions clause for thread::join() is:
discussion.blockquote: Postconditions: If join() throws an exception, the value returned by get_id() is unchanged. Otherwise, get_id() == id().
Throws: std::system_error when the postconditions cannot be achieved.
discussion.p: Now... how could the postconditions not be achieved? It's just a matter of resetting the value of get_id() or leave it unchanged! I bet we can always do that. Moreover, it's a chicken-and-egg problem: in order to decide whether to throw or not I depend on the postconditions, but the postconditions are different in the two cases.
I believe the throws clause should be:
discussion.blockquote: Throws: std::system_error when the effects or postconditions cannot be achieved.
discussion.p: as it is in detach(), or, even better, as the postcondition is trivially satisfiable and to remove the circular dependency:
discussion.blockquote: Throws: std::system_error if the effects cannot be achieved.
discussion.p: Problem is that... ehm... join() has no "Effects" clause. Is that intentional?
discussion.note: See the thread starting at c++std-lib-23204 for more discussion.

p.ins: Effects: Blocks until the thread represented by *this has completed.

blockquote.p: 6 Synchronization: The completion of the thread represented by *this happens before () join() returns. [Note: Operations on *this are not synchronized. — end note]
7 Postconditions: If join() throws an exception, the value returned by get_id() is unchanged. Otherwise, The thread represented by *this has completed. get_id() == id().
